http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-12-03/venezuela-congress-election-what-to-watch-as-results-come-in Understanding the results won’t be easy though as a majority of the popular vote doesn’t necessarily translate into more seats in the assembly. Some seats are awarded by direct voting, some through party lists. It may take several days before a clear picture of what’s to come emerges . . . 
~~~~~~~
“Only a grotesque fraud could stop the opposition from winning a simple majority,” said the head of a Caracas-based consulting firm Polity and political science professor at Central Venezuela University
~~~~~~~
The numbers:
167 seats in national assembly 
113 members of parliament are elected based on first-past-the-post, 
51 members are elected through closed party lists using proportional representation, 
3 seats are reserved for indigenous peoples.  84 (simple majority) are needed to veto government measures, such as a national budget. 
100 (3/5ths) are needed to censure ministers,
111 (2/3rds) are needed to change the constitution and appoint supreme court justices.

Let's consider the ways PSUV might win
-the polls are wrong.  pollsters have traditionally underestimated electoral support for Chavismo
-PSUV has for years demonstrated an ability to mobilize its voters
-government intimidation of opposition
-7 opposition leaders have been banned from running for office
-4 opposition leaders are imprisoned. 
-electoral fraud:  no qualified electoral observation from the OAS or EU
-gerrymandered districts so that 52% of voters, in pro-opposition urban areas, elect just 39% of parliament,
-The electoral map is set up to dilute opposition ballots. So while a candidate in a pro-government district might win a spot with 10,000 votes, a rival in an opposition stronghold might need 350,000 votes to win the seat. “It’s not enough just to win,” León said. “You have to double the votes that your adversary might get.” As a result “the opposition might be a clear majority but may control Congress by a narrow margin,” 
-fake parties with names mimicking legitimate opposition parties to confuse voters.
-government-imposed state of emergency in swing states in the west prevents opposition campaigning
-refusal to renew broadcasting licenses to opposition media
-the low-cost food program swayed voters
-continuing affection for Chavez
 -doing “whatever it takes.” Venezuelans understand exactly what he means. The ways MUD might lose
-failure to turn out to vote.  no comparable get out the vote organization or campaign to PSUVs
-the polls were wrong.  polls are notoriously unreliable in Venezuela
-electoral fraud
-has long struggled to maintain cohesion, let alone formulate a clear electoral platform beyond simple opposition to Chavismo. Bottomline:  Maduro has a lot of tools he can use to turn the "will of the people" his way.  I'm wondering if I've gone too negative on PSUV.

Updating and decreasing my probability estimate based on all the recent articles that have been collected below.  However, as I have stated before,  never underestimate the ability of whatever party/junta/dictator that may rule at any given time to maintain their position and power, and remember that the military is the real center of power in Venezuela.

Several factors most likely will determine the outcome.   Political patronage (Colectivos) at community and ellite levels in the government, the control of the National Electoral Commission, high polling numbers for the opposition in certain areas in the country - it does not accurately reflect a national level of polling, Maduro's stated intent to move the Venezuela to civilian-military rule (if it looses a majority to the opposition) and a single electoral observer that is tightly connected to and approves the Venezuelan political system and it's status quo. What civilian-military rule implies is likely that the party (representing the civilian institutions and life) and the military will gain increased control over the Venezuelan bureacracy.  Perhaps military rule guised in this form?  The role of patronage (corruptions) since Chavez's rule, dissident repression, misrepresentation on ballots (MID Unity with a candidate whose name is similar to the candidate for MUD unity) and the transition to Maduro is deeply rooted in political institutions controlled by the party (judiciary, electoral commission, executive, political elites, and so on) are constraints faced by any opposition to Maduro and his party. I am decreasing the estimate only to reflect a balance against previous forecasts, should the Chavismo movement win. For the opposition, it is always good to note that polling numbers DO NOT necessarily translate into VOTES.  The is no direct observable relationship among these two factors.  A large turnout for the opposition (with a low turnout for the ruling party) implies an increase in seats for the opposition in parliament.  However, obtaining a majority in a socialist-authoritarian state by an opposition parties

http://america.aljazeera.com/opinions/2015/11/venezuelas-electoral-system-is-being-unfairly-maligned.html Quote #1:
While the outlook appears grim for Maduro’s Chavista government, the final vote tally may disappoint the opposition. The opposition needs to win all swing districts to get a majority, and the Chavista get-out-the-vote effort has historically been far superior to the opposition’s. “As in previous elections, the opposition campaign has been abstract and content free,” Smilde observed earlier this month. Yet Maduro’s dismal approval ratings and mounting public frustration over economic hardships may obscure the opposition’s failure to articulate a substantive platform. Critics warn that Maduro may resort to fraud and violence if his party loses its majority in the National Assembly. However, there is no evidence he will reject the results. In fact, as Smilde and others have pointed out, Maduro appears to be anticipating legislative losses. And some in the opposition have too often responded to losses with violence, property destruction and calls for extralegal means to achieve what they could not at the ballot box. Let’s hope they are not emboldened by the efforts of Almagro and others to discredit the elections either by making unfounded allegations of fraud or by reprising the destabilizing, violent unrest that rocked Venezuela last year. Quote #2 - VE electoral system:
Venezuelan voters use electronic machines, which print out a paper receipt that allows voters to check their choices against the electronic ballot. After voting has ended, 54 percent of machines are audited at random, in the presence of witnesses from pro-government and opposition political parties, and compared with a tally of paper receipts. The National Electoral Council (CNE) has implemented additional safeguards and audits, making the process more inclusive than ever before, with 96.5 percent of eligible Venezuelans registered to vote (compared with fewer than 76 percent of eligible Americans). With the support of the Carter Center (a nonprofit organization run by Jimmy Carter and Rosalynn Carter) and other pro-democracy groups, Venezuela has developed strong, independent national observation groups. “Despite refusal of the CNE to allow substantial international observation, its relationship with domestic observers has actually improved,” according to David Smilde, a senior fellow at the advocacy group Washington Office on Latin America. “They have been granted almost twice as many credentials as they had three years ago, which improves their capacity.”
---

Probably my last before the poll itself, barring something unexpected happening. There are four sources I'm considering: 
1) The projection of the opinion polls, adjusted according to historical opposition underpolling and the skew of the electoral system to rural votes. This projects that PSUV will have 35% of the seats in the National Assembly (MUD should have 46%). So that's a pretty emphatic loss of control. I'm weighting this 60%.
2) Turnout for Primaries - PSUV's turnout was twice that of MUD. Using this as a proxy for grassroots strength, that suggests PSUV will keep control. I'm weighting this 20%.
3) A referendum on the government/status quo. I spotted this link on another prediction (it was a link from the article linked to by @Dima K), but basically if you plug the current "positivity" rating (12%) into the tool, you end up with similar numbers to the adjusted opinion polling projection (36% for PSUV). To be honest, I'm not convinced - it worked well in 2010, but there are lots of explanations that suggest correlation and not causation. Still, I'm weighting this 10%.
4) The chance of the poll being stolen/disrupted. I was inclined to ignore this, as it felt like 3rd world/populist snobbery, but there have been some signs (helpfully pointed out by @vox vox) that there have been more than usual shenanigans around dodgy electoral practices. Based upon what I've read, while I think there will be some dodginess, I think there is only a 30% chance this could determine the poll.  I'm weighting this 10%. To put a proper number on the prob. of a PSUV majority is rather complex in general, particularly in a situation where the integrity of the elections is not 100% guaranteed.  To do that, I have to put a probability on the event that the PSUV could win a majority given the current poll numbers.  This probability can be split into two pieces: P( PSUV maintain majority fairly | poll numbers ) + P( PSUV maintain majority unfairly | poll numbers). To translate poll numbers into seats, one needs to understand the efficiency of each party's vote which I don't claim to. So using last election as a rough guide, I'll assume that with 40% of the vote the PSUV wins 50% of the seats. So now the probability we're trying to estimate becomes  P( PSUV wins 40% of the vote FAIRLY | poll numbers ) + P( PSUV wins 40% of the vote UNFAIRLY | poll numbers). For simplicity, lets call these P1 and P2, and let's start with P1:  - The average of the November polls according to wikipedia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venezuelan_parliamentary_election,_2015#Electoral_system)  is 
PSUV ~ 26%, MUD ~ 51%, independents (what does this mean?) ~ 11% and undecideds ~ 12%. 
- This puts the relative polling numbers (disregarding ind's and undecideds) at about 33% to 66%. So, the polls have to be off by 7% (in the right direction) for the PSUV  to hit 40%. 
- This shouldn't be more than a 1% event at best, so let's be extra conservative and set P1=2%.  Now let's examine P2:  - The question now becomes can the PSUV, through unfair tactics, sway 7% of the vote to their side (assuming the poll average is accurate). Note that tactics they have been accused of using include intimidation (e.g., killing an opposition politician thereby discouraging opposition rallies), vote rigging (which considering the discussion in the previous comments is not impossible), and playing games like running separate candidates with the same  name as opposition candidates, or having similarly named parties appear on the ballot. 
- Say intimidation moves 2% of the relative vote in their favor (say via vote suppression), and assume minimal/no vote rigging (say another 1%?), and let's say the confusing ballots work on 1-2% of the oppositions' voters. 
-Now our gap shrank from 7% to possibly 2% (assuming accurate poll averages).
-Assume polls are right to within 2% 19 times out of 20.  
-This puts a 5% chance that the polls are off by more than 2% and a 2.5% (say 3%) chance they are off in the PSUV's direction.  Boosting P2 (as we did P1) by 1% we end up with a 6% estimate for the PSUV. 
I had been planning to gradually move the needle on this one, but thanks to Dima K's comments (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/50101) on a previous forecast, here it goes .

- Latest polls have the opposition up by anywhere between 15 and 24%. This should ensure an opposition win considering that we're only 10 days away from the election. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venezuelan_parliamentary_election,_2015#Opinion_polls. Since we are 10 days out, I am assigning a baseline of 10% for the PSUV maintaining its majority.  - On the other hand, an opposition politician was killed today http://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-34929332, potentially signaling some intimidation tactics (which may or may not backfire). I am (rather arbitrarily) increasing the PSUV's chance to 15% under the assumption that they wouldn't have done it if they didn't think it would help them (that said, one could just as easily argue that this is a sign of desperation).  - The electoral system is such that it overrepresents the PSUV (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venezuelan_parliamentary_election,_2015#Electoral_system). Last time around the vote was essentially evenly split but the PSUV had about 60% of the seats. I am increasing the PSUV's chances to 20% accordingly.  - Lack of election observers: http://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-34797775. another 5%.  Brings us to 25%. - I'm ready to decrease this as needed if more polls/information come in.

I suppose that depends on what "after" means. Maduro has said that the revolution will win "como sea" — "by hook or by crook." Maduro and PSUV have already done a bit of gerrymandering to favor the PSUV. If "como sea" means that the PSUV will not recognize unfavorable results, and by some maneuver, retain its seats or seat its candidates regardless of the results, then yes, there is a high probability that it will retain its majority. If it means that the tallied results show that it didn't retain its majority, then likely no, but almost certainly Maduro and the PSUV will try to annul those results. Whether he can muster enough force to do that is an open question; he doesn't have the popular support, though. http://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/world/americas/venezuela/article44569893.html#storylink=cpy "For the first time in more than a decade, all major polls show that the opposition is running far ahead in next month’s legislative races. . . .  “What we’re hearing from people is rage, disgust, discomfort,” said . . .  a pollster with the firm Meganalisis, which gives the opposition an 11-point lead in the upcoming election. “In my 36 years of doing this, I’ve never seen this level of voter discontent.” "Manuel Rios, 60, a retired military officer, . . . .  is convinced the administration has lost its bedrock, Venezuela’s poorest, because of constant shortages and massive lines. In a country that boasts of having the world’s largest oil reserves, Rios said he has been bathing with blue-tinctured medical soap because he can’t find a regular bar.
. . . 
"But Venezuela’s 21st Century Socialism still has adherents. And many buy the administration’s claims that it’s under attack. In their telling, the opposition, along with powerful international allies, are hoarding goods, sabotaging the electrical grid and promoting violence to push the nation into chaos. Luisa Crespo, who had approached the mock voting center, said she fears an opposition-led Congress might eliminate the housing, food and medical subsidies that have been hallmarks of the ruling party. “They want to control the government again because this is the golden goose, a wealthy country, full of petroleum and minerals,” she said. “They’re not going to win Congress, but if they did, the people would rise up against them.” "Beyond the faithful, more than a decade of rule has allowed the administration to amass a series of electoral advantages both blatant and subtle. Perhaps the clearest example is the redistricting that has taken place in recent years.  Luis Vicente León, whose Datanálisis polls are closely watched, said that even if the opposition were heading into the campaign with a 20- or 30-point advantage, it wouldn’t necessarily translate into more deputies.  The electoral map is set up to dilute opposition ballots. So while a candidate in a pro-government district might win a spot with 10,000 votes, a rival in an opposition stronghold might need 350,000 votes to win the seat. “It’s not enough just to win,” León said. “You have to double the votes that your adversary might get.”  As a result “the opposition might be a clear majority but may control Congress by a narrow margin,” he added. "In addition, the National Electoral Council, which is firmly under the administration’s control, has allowed maneuvers that would raise eyebrows in more robust democracies.  On the December ballot, the box for the coalition of opposition parties known as the Mesa de Unidad Democática, or MUD, sits adjacent to that of MIN-Unidad, which has similar colors and typeface. And while MIN-Unidad’s motto is “We’re the opposition,” the MUD accuses it of being a ruling-party red-herring designed to sap votes.  If the move was designed to provoke confusion, it seemed to be working during the mock election.  As Eliana Hernández, 19, studied a sample ballot, she said that any party that has the word “unity” in it is the opposition. “They’re all pretty much the same,” she said. "The government also seems to embrace subliminal psychology. Hundreds of new polling stations have been created for the legislative race and many have been christened with highly partisan names.  As a result, on Dec. 6, voters will be lining up at polling stations called the “Pure Socialist Blood of Chávez,” the “Eternal Commander Chávez” and “With Chávez and Maduro.”
That the electoral body would allow the names is just another sign of how corrupt the system is, said Henry Ramos Allup, the president of the opposition Acción Democrática party. “This is a profanity,” he said.  "The Organization of American States last week said “transparency and electoral justice” were not guaranteed during the vote. The body cited the jailing of opposition candidates, biased media coverage and other obstacles. Venezuela denied the OAS the right to observe the elections, but has said it will allow representatives from the Union of South American Nations (UNASUR) to “accompany” the vote. ". . . one of the poll workers during Sunday’s exercise, said the opposition knows it’s going to lose and is preparing the groundwork to declare fraud. On Sunday, each . . .  was responsible for bringing 10 people to the mock poll and those 10 each had to bring an additional 10 — an electoral pyramid scheme she said would ensure victory.  “We’ll have a large margin of victory because we’re well organized and have the party machinery,”’ she predicted. “This election isn’t even going to be close.”

Current opinion polls have the opposition MUD leading PSUV ~50% to ~30%, so I'm translating that proportionally to a 27% yes for PSUV keeping their majority. However, the PSUV "ground game" can't be ignored - their primary turnout was twice that of the opposition. So if that translates effectively to a 66% poll in favour of PSUV, the mean of the two is 46%.  There are three main factors I'm not considering (yet): the election not happening (which I assume counts as a 'No'), the results are tampered with and finally complicated electoral arithmetic (what is it with the Americas and complicated electoral systems?). Given unrest similar to last year or, heaven forbid, a natural disaster, the poll might not happen. While generally Venezuelan elections are considered fair, a previously supportive Brazil has recently pulled out of monitoring this poll. Finally, the electoral system apparently favours the rural vote more than the cities, although it would have to be to a significant degree to influence things, as the country's urbanisation rate is 90%. http://laht.com/article.asp?ArticleId=2399114&CategoryId=10717 Maduro is deeply unpopular, but this is not news.  In the last election cycle (Nov 2013) he overcame his unpopularity by forcing distributors of household appliances to sell all their in-stock merchandise at prices below cost, causing a "Black Friday" event that scoured stores clean of merchandise because it forced prices down to where many were able to buy products beyond their financial reach.  This had a positive impact on the municipal election results for the candidates of PSUV, though the long-term consequences were disastrous shortages and high prices, the closure of many small businesses that were not able to recover from the economic impact, the inability of many other medium-sized businesses that have had a hard time replenishing their inventories, and the loss of hundreds of jobs. "Now, when all opinion polls are showing that the Government will not be able to revert a rate of popular discontent that already exceeds 80% because of its mismanagement of the country, it has decided to reform the Law of Fair Prices in order to require that manufacturers and importers set the respective Maximum Selling Price to the Public (PMVP) at factories or warehouses of importers, including the costs and profit margins for all wholesalers and retailers from the entire chain to the final consumer. . . . Moreover, if the dollar sold on the parallel market becomes part of the cost structure it will be considered a foreign exchange crime; a measure that will further impact companies that resorted to dollars of the parallel market to replenish their inventories due to the impossibility of obtaining foreign currency at official rates. " . . .  The reform of this law also increased sanctions that now include imprisonment, fines and confiscation of goods and proceeds involved.  A "National Commando of Fair Prices," created with the reform of the law, was activated on October 23, . .  [which] will supposedly be focusing efforts on the "protection of the income of the people" by fighting speculation. Since then, retail stores and distributors are receiving the unpleasant visit of these "commandos," forcing them to sell their products between 10% and 30% below their list prices – or, at a loss while marked prices were already complying with the previous regulation.
~~~~~~~

Link:  http://www.as-coa.org/articles/summary-venezuelas-december-elections-democratic-turning-point Given the authoritarian nature of the political system in Venezuela, several factors may indicating the shifting and uncertain nature of legislative or political outcomes in general.  The role of increase political repression, the Dakazo phenomenon (transforming political discontent into positive electoral outcomes, and ideological cohesion among the electorate, can potentially guarantee PSUVs hold on the National Assembly. However, ideology in the face of hunger, persistent poverty, increasingly devalued currency, limited economic growth and deep inequality, may mean little given the level of deprivation and frustration.   Increases in the number of demonstrations (2800), arrests of activists and the discontent, looting and low level violence among the population (not directed at the state),  may not be sufficient to shift the dominance of the party/state.  State corruption could help shift electoral dominance in the direction of the state but may not be sufficient given the level of public despair and discontent in Venezuela. It is however highly likely that the dominance of the state and its ideological mechanisms will allow it to retain legislative power despite limited changes in the economic, social and political realms next year.
